Legal_Issue: Whether the plaintiff can obtain an interlocutory injunction for alleged infringement of industrial design
Evidence_Assessment: Substantial similarity in stroller designs, evidence of copying, defendant's arguments on originality and registration validity not conclusive
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must show serious question to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience
Legal_Rule: Interlocutory injunctions require a serious question to be tried, irreparable harm, and balance of convenience favoring the applicant
Standard_of_Review: Balance of convenience, risk of irreparable harm
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of registered industrial design for baby strollers
Key_Evidence_Considered: Design similarity, copying evidence, validity of registration
Legal_Framework: Industrial design law, principles of equitable remedies
Applicant_Challenge: Demonstrating risk of irreparable harm and likelihood of success at trial
Legal_Rule_Source: Common law principles on interlocutory injunctions
Standard_of_Proof: Serious question to be tried (intermediate threshold)
Defendant_Response: Challenged originality and validity of plaintiff's design registration
Remedy_Sought: Prevention of sale of allegedly infringing strollers
Governing_Rule: Principles governing interlocutory injunctions in intellectual property cases
